speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: SCENE IX. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: SALARINO
text_entry: Enter NERISSA with a Servitor

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Quick, quick, I pray thee; draw the curtain straight:

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: And comes to his election presently.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Flourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE OF ARRAGON, PORTIA, and their trains

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble prince:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you choose that wherein I am contain'd,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But if you fail, without more speech, my lord,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You must be gone from hence immediately.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I am enjoin'd by oath to observe three things:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: First, never to unfold to any one

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Which casket 'twas I chose; next, if I fail

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Of the right casket, never in my life

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To woo a maid in way of marriage: Lastly,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: If I do fail in fortune of my choice,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Immediately to leave you and be gone.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To these injunctions every one doth swear

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That comes to hazard for my worthless self.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And so have I address'd me. Fortune now

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To my heart's hope! Gold; silver; and base lead.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: You shall look fairer, ere I give or hazard.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What says the golden chest? ha! let me see:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What many men desire! that 'many' may be meant

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: By the fool multitude, that choose by show,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach;

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Which pries not to the interior, but, like the martlet,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Builds in the weather on the outward wall,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Even in the force and road of casualty.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I will not choose what many men desire,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Because I will not jump with common spirits

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Why, then to thee, thou silver treasure-house;

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Tell me once more what title thou dost bear:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves:'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And well said too; for who shall go about

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To cozen fortune and be honourable

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Without the stamp of merit? Let none presume

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To wear an undeserved dignity.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: O, that estates, degrees and offices

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Were not derived corruptly, and that clear honour

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Were purchased by the merit of the wearer!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How many then should cover that stand bare!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How many be commanded that command!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How much low peasantry would then be glean'd

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: From the true seed of honour! and how much honour

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Pick'd from the chaff and ruin of the times

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: To be new-varnish'd! Well, but to my choice:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I will assume desert. Give me a key for this,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: And instantly unlock my fortunes here.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: He opens the silver casket

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Too long a pause for that which you find there.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What's here? the portrait of a blinking idiot,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Presenting me a schedule! I will read it.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How much unlike art thou to Portia!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: How much unlike my hopes and my deservings!

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: 'Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves.'

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Did I deserve no more than a fool's head?

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Is that my prize? are my deserts no better?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To offend, and judge, are distinct offices

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And of opposed natures.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: What is here?

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Reads

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: The fire seven times tried this:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Seven times tried that judgment is,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: That did never choose amiss.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Some there be that shadows kiss;

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Such have but a shadow's bliss:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: There be fools alive, I wis,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Silver'd o'er; and so was this.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Take what wife you will to bed,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: I will ever be your head:

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: So be gone: you are sped.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Still more fool I shall appear

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: By the time I linger here

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: With one fool's head I came to woo,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: But I go away with two.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Sweet, adieu. I'll keep my oath,

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Patiently to bear my wroth.

speaker: ARRAGON
text_entry: Exeunt Arragon and train

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thus hath the candle singed the moth.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: O, these deliberate fools! when they do choose,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: The ancient saying is no heresy,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Come, draw the curtain, Nerissa.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Where is my lady?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Here: what would my lord?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Madam, there is alighted at your gate

speaker: Servant
text_entry: A young Venetian, one that comes before

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To signify the approaching of his lord;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: From whom he bringeth sensible regreets,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To wit, besides commends and courteous breath,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Gifts of rich value. Yet I have not seen

speaker: Servant
text_entry: So likely an ambassador of love:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: A day in April never came so sweet,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To show how costly summer was at hand,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: As this fore-spurrer comes before his lord.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: No more, I pray thee: I am half afeard

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thou spend'st such high-day wit in praising him.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Come, come, Nerissa; for I long to see

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Quick Cupid's post that comes so mannerly.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Bassanio, lord Love, if thy will it be!

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Exeunt
